definitions.definition: a hall in a public building that is used for formal meetings

examples.text: The members left the council chamber.
He had to answer some tricky questions from the floor of the debating chamber.
She is due to deliver a speech in the senate chamber.

definitions.definition: one of the parts of a parliament

examples.text: the **Lower/Upper Chamber** *(= in Britain, the House of Commons/House of Lords)*
The party has gained more seats in the Chamber of Deputies in the Italian parliament.
Under Senate rules, the chamber must vote on the bill by this Friday.
The chamber has/have been very vocal in supporting these initiatives.
She believes there should be an elected second chamber to replace the House of Lords.
There are plans to abolish the non-elected upper chamber of the federal legislature.
They are seeking to overturn the Liberal majority in the second chamber.

definitions.definition: a room used for the particular purpose that is mentioned
a space in the body, in a plant or in a machine that is separated from the rest

examples.text: the chamber of a gun *(= the part that holds the bullets)*

definitions.definition: a space under the ground that is almost completely closed on all sides

examples.text: They found themselves in a vast underground chamber.
Lady Eleanor was found dead in her chamber.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘private room’): from Old French chambre, from Latin camera ‘vault, arched chamber’, from Greek kamara ‘object with an arched cover’.
